title: OPO vs. BB Passport battery life

thread.text:
I've had my BlackBerry Passport since launch last September. I've had the OPO for about six weeks, give or take. The Passport battery is rated at 3,450 mAh; the OPO at 3,100 mAh. In terms of pixels, the screens of the two devices are the same, at about 2.07 million pixels. Both screens are LCD. The OPO's CPU is clocked slightly faster, at 2.5 Ghz, compared to the Passport's 2.26 Ghz. Both have 3 GB of RAM. In short, they are very similar in the specs that matter to battery life.
Since buying the OPO, I've been switching phones every so often, for several days to a week at a time; and I've been keeping an informal battery life log. That is, I just write down how much charge is left when I put the phone on the charger when I go to bed. My usage habits don't change that much. I listen to podcasts in the car, do some WhatsApp messaging, receive a fair amount of email, read a bit on the Kindle app, kill time playing Desert Golfing, update apps, and so on. If I watch any video, it's the odd YouTube clip that someone sends out a link to. I almost never watch a movie or TV program on my phone. A fair amount of web browsing.
Network reception in my office is poor, so even with wifi on, a certain amount of battery power is wasted as the phones drop the network connection and try to get it back.
I keep the settings the same on both phones. GPS always on; screen timeout at 30 seconds, medium brightness, etc.
After doing this for almost a month, my results are:
1. Both devices get more than satisfactory battery life. That is, they have power to spare when I charge them at night.
2. The OPO typically has more power left over than the Passport. Usually, the Passport is down to about 20% when I go to bed. The OPO is almost always above 30%.
This is surprising, since the Passport has a substantially bigger battery. Moreover, the "common wisdom" in the BlackBerry community is that Android itself is inherently inefficient. This common wisdom, like a lot of common wisdom, appears to be wrong.
I wonder if what's draining the battery faster on the Passport is the use of some Android apps that use the baked-in Android runtime. Checking battery stats on the Passport seems to confirm this.
I use Greenify on my OPO, which I can't use on the Passport. But the Passport has settings that allow me to block apps from running when minimized/closed, so the effect should be similar. I have roughly the same suite of apps on both devices, except for utilities that are device-specific.
So, I'm just posting this here in case anyone's curious about it.

Wow this is very interesting. I was thinking about getting a passport because I thought the battery life would be amazing but I guess its not as good at this phone. Thanks for the post!
Posted via the OnePlus One On Oxygen OS

I have both and it is indeed the android runtime and apps that makes the battery life of the blackberry PP less. Running less of the android runtime I get way better battery life that the OPO. I had installed the play store and a bunch of apps from it but then decided it wasn't worth it and installed them all.

I've heard some people say the Play store itself eats battery on the Passport. But I haven't installed it. I use Snap which doesn't run in the background. I also don't keep android apps running, but apparently when they are running in the foreground they use a lot of juice. 
But I still consider the Passport's battery life to be very good.

That's good to know I guess. I used to get about 2 full days with my OnePlus One before weird battery drains started in the last month or so. And I get about a good day and half on my Z30 which has a smaller battery than the Passport. 
I still want to try the Passport again (owned it for a week but sold it for a profit) once it get down to about $500 taxes in... By then though the slider may be out and we'll have to see what that offers.

I own both devices as well. I tend to switch between the 2 every couple of days and It really is difficult to decide on which one lasts me longer because everyday presents a new way that I use my phone.
Having used a variety of devices, I can safely say that both the Passport and One Plus One have given me satisfactory battery life and this one feature is always at the top of my must-have list when making the decision to purchase a new device.

replies.text:
Agreed. I don't want to have to charge my phone before I go to bed at night. I know there are people who don't do this, but let the phone run down the next day before charging in the middle of the day. I honestly don't know why they do this, but I know a lot of people do it. Although my usage patterns don't vary that much, there are certainly days when I use the phone more -- especially when I have to do some navigating -- so I like to have enough extra power for those occasions.
So far, I think CM12s (Lollipop) isn't quite as good as CM11s in terms of battery life, but it's still acceptable.

title: Windows Phone user looking for comparable Android experience, what should I get?

thread.text:
Hello, I've just ordered a OnePlus One. I've been using Windows Phone for years and really really liked the platform. I decided to move to Android since I can get all of the positive parts of Windows Phone including the UX, with the use of some apps (like Launcher 8), and I can also get all of the stuff that Windows phone doesn't have like decent flagship hardware and apps that get updated regularly.
There are some things that I'm hoping some other people who may have moved from Windows Phone might be able to help with. 
1. Looking for a good calendar application. I really liked the one on Windows phone, I use my Calendar a lot for business and this is important to me.
2. I would go ahead and use the new Microsoft Outlook app but last I checked they store credentials on their server (this is inherited from Acompli which MS bought). So with that said, what is a good, secure email client for Android that provides a similar or better experience to Windows Phone?
I'm sure once my phone actually arrives I'll have lots more questions and I'll be sure to ask them here. 
Thanks in Advance!

Welcome to the forums!
1. I personally use Google Calendar, but Today Calendar is also a really good one.
2. The Gmail app now supports third party email accounts, including your hotmail/outlook address
Edit: Forgot to mention that I am not an ex-Windows user. Just giving my two cents

title: Dismal Oneplus One Service

thread.text:
I thought I would give one plus a shot.
I got the phone on 5th Jan and on 2nd Feb it stopped detecting network. I gave it to the service center on 4th of Feb. On 6th Feb I was told that the phone has a hardware problem and you would be getting a replacement. I was told you would receive the phone on 10th feb.
Called up on 10th Feb - The phone has not reached the service center. They said I would get the phone on 13th.
Called up on 13th Feb - The phone has not reached the service center. They said I would get the phone on 17th.
Called up on 17th Feb - The phone has not reached the service center. They said I would get the phone on 20th. I was positively told that I would receive it before that day.
20th Feb. Called up service center at 4pm and service center told me that they have not received a replacement.
Called up oneplus support and they want another week.
I am sorry but this is absolute bonkers of service.
Its 2nd March 2015 :- And the same thing is going on. Still haven't received my phone. 
08th March : No sign of the phone yet.

OnePlus is still getting its act together. They can't afford to have 5,000 phones sitting on the shelf for a week. They're basically making them as they're ordered. (You think 3 months is bad? When Motorola first came out with cellphones, you got one in about 6 months. That was to buy one - 6 months after you ordered it and put down a deposit. I never tried to have one replaced - I'd probably still be waiting. Mobile service was better when it first came out - that only took about 2 weeks after you paid for it to have the phone installed in the car.)
If people keep buying their phones (you have to admit that you're getting a lot of phone for the money), they'll grow to the point that they can keep replacements locally, and you can bring in the defective one and walk out with the replacement. Not yet, though.

title: Moto X -> OnePlus One Transition, Active Display Replacement?

thread.text:
Hi All,
After tons of problems with my VZW Moto X (2014) with zero resolution from Verizon, I've decided to grab a OnePlus One. I picked up a used 64gb on Swappa for a song.
The only thing I can think of that I'm going to miss about the Moto vs. the OPO is Active Display. I've gotten quite accustomed to seeing everything at a glance, being able to wave my hand over my phone, and the gimmicky stuff that makes the Moto X such a great phone (when Verizon isn't "optimizing the user experience" with phone-breaking bugs).
I know there are a couple of apps on the app store designed to essentially be Active Display for non-Moto phones, but I'm wondering which is you guys' favorite for the OPO, if anyone is using such a thing.
Thanks!

replies.text: I use Dynamic Notifications and have been since it launched. It has a ton of features.https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...ications&hl=en

Thanks! I know it's not the same without an AMOLED, but I'll check it out.I will be switching to T-Mobile as soon as the phone arrives and I verify that it's in working order. My best friend is a manager at T-Mobile and Verizon keeps getting crappier and crappier and pricier and pricier. I can save myself and my family some scratch by switching.
You will love T-Mobile, I made the switch from Sprint a while back and couldn't be happier with my data speeds.

Yeah, I re-upped with Verizon at a previous job where I had to travel all around the state and needed the coverage, but at this point, the VZW variants of phones are consistently crappier and buggier than their competitors' phones, and the fact that their stuff is so locked down that you can't download/sideload fixes is so irritating. If I were paying like HALF of what I am right now it would MAYBE be acceptable.
Right now my MMS are topped out at 30kb thumbnails, sound only works half the time, only about 2/3 of my texts go through, bluetooth is completely broken, and battery life is abysmal. These are all issues that seem unique to the VZW variant of the Moto X based on my limited research, and all they were willing to do for me as a fifteen-year customer was offer me a refurb, non-moto-maker, for $150.
Enough's enough.

Just a heads up, tmoble is a lot more expensive for larger data plans than att, depends how much data you will be using
Posted via the Android Central App

If you're willing to flash the OPO, there is a very similar feature to the Moto X active display in the CyanogenMod 12 ROM. It's probably coming to the official 12S release, but I decided to flash mine. Process was pretty simple and it's even more stable than the official CM 11S release I've been running.

Posted via the Android Central App

I've had 2 new Note 3s and one refurb, on the same carrier (I guess I'm lucky that way). All with the same apps installed (and the same data in the apps). They were all over the place with AnTuTu. Not that AnTuTu is bad, the CPU speed is "nominal" - you can get a faster clock or a slower clock just based on component tolerances. Tighter tolerances cost more, and the CCPU speed doesn't affect the phone much, so I guess the manufacturers don't care if their 1.5GHz phone is running at 1.49GHz or 1.51GHz.
Yours seems to be just about exactly as fast as the "average" one.

replies.text:
Well, to be honest....... I'm more impressed with the performance of this phone than any phone I've had, and I've had The Note 4, the note edge, lg g3, HTC m8, note 3, iPhone 6 and 6 plus. The Oneplus One is the powerhouse of the group. It does not waist its power on stupid things like UV sensors, and heart rate monitors and stuff. If I want my BP or heart rate taken I go to my doctor. If I want to write something down I use a pen and paper. I want my cell phone to let me watch movies, take great pictures, talk and text, play a game or two and most of all.............let me make my phone what I want it to be. And none of that at the expense or trading battery life for performance. My Oneplus one keeps up with me all day, and I'm on my phone for a long long time. Bottom line I love this phone.

replies.text:
How are you liking the OPO overall? I remember you got the moto x and returned it. Not sure if you ever tried the Nexus 6. The OPO is great device!
Posted via my Nexus 6!

I must say I'm enjoying my OPO very much, and am glad I went through the trouble to return the Moto X (I just couldn't deal with the camera).
With the OPO, I have a more affordable device (I got the $350 64GB version), that has much better specs and a much better camera. The screen is a bit too big for my personal taste, but it's nothing I can't get used to (and already am. When I pick up my Nexus 5, it feels tiny now!). Besides the screen size, everything else is great. 
Good speakers. Great reception and GPS signal. Gorgeous screen. Battery life is phenomenal (went to bed with 64% left after 14+ hours off the charger and 2.5+ hours of SOT from an average use day). I just don't worry about battery life anymore. It's a lovely feeling. 
And more importantly, Cyonogen is great. It's stock Android "Plus" -- small tweaks and smart additions to the software that really add to the overall experience in nearly every way. It would take me forever to list all the helpful tweaks. It makes things easier and more fun. Software-wise, I think Cyonogen beats Moto's version of Android. I can safely say I don't miss anything from the Moto X (except for maybe one thing: I wish the white back was an option for the OPO's 64GB level). 
And I certainly don't miss anything from my Nexus 5 (though I can't wait to get Lollipop on the OPO). 
Lastly, when I consider the value of the OPO, then I get even happier! $350 dollars for top-tier specs (a lot of which is very future-proof. I mean, 3GB of RAM?), amazing software that is, in my opinion, better than stock Android, and beautiful/reliable hardware, all unlocked with proper T-Mobile GSM and LTE radios... it's just insane. 
Best phone I've owned to date. It's a real shame the invite system was so badly implemented to turn people off from this device. It's a real gem.
PS. Never got to really try the N6 except for in-store model. Looks and sounds like a lovely device, but I am happy with my OPO choice especially considering the N6 screen size and price point (too big, too high!).

title: Any way to play Flash on OPO?

thread.text:
Any way to play Flash on OPO?
A certain browser or anything?
Sent from my 64gb Sandstone One Plus One aka Opal the OPO
Flash Player 4.x. The Dolphin browser uses it nicely.
Puffin has integrated flash

For what it's worth I would highly suggest against using a direct installation of Flash on Android as Adobe has announced complete abandonment (as of September, 2013) of Flash, including security updates.Manually Install on Android DevicesArchived Flash Player VersionsAdobe Roadmap for the Flash Runtimes
Scroll down to 'Mobile'Flash Player 11.1 is the last release of the Flash Player plug-in for mobile browsers. Adobe will not add support for new mobile device configurations (chipset, browser, OS version, etc.). Adobe will continue to provide critical bug fixes and security updates for existing device configurations through September 2013, and will also allow our source-code licensees to continue working on and releasing their own implementations.
Although Dolphin supports Flash it is not sandboxed (as is, for example, the 'Pepper' Flash Player built into and sandboxed in desktop versions of Chrome) and requires separate installation of the unsupported Flash.
Flashfox and flashify... The first one is a Firefox based browser with flash included. The second one allows to open your current page in any browser using Flashfox via the share button.

title: Does need antivirus?

thread.text: As thread heading says... am planning to order a new one, just wanted to know if this needs any antivirus apps to be installed? Does it have any preinstalled?

Anything connected to the internet should have one. If there's no virus written for the operating system (and there are plenty for Android) one will be soon.
I don't know of a phone that comes with a good one (Samsung phones come with Lookout - which has a bug in Samsung phones, so it has to be turned off), but you should install AdWare, Malwarebytes Anti-Malware and an antivirus like Avast Mobile Security & Antivirus, AVG AntiVirus Security, Avira Antivirus Security or Kaspersky Internet Security on your phone.

If you only download apps from the play store and only from well known developers the probability you run into some malware is relatively small. If you plan to install random apks from outside the playstore you should install a antivirus app. It doesn't have one preinstalled.

title: Can I get some help with my battery charging?

thread.text:
Hi everyone!
I have a oneplus one, and when ends the day, I put to charge my phone with 50 percent to 20 percent.
It is bad for the battery of my oneplus one?
THANKS

Welcome to Android Central! Sorry, can you clarify your question? Is the phone at 50 percent or 20 percent at the end of the day?
In general, make it a habit to recharge your phone when it gets to around 40%. Letting it drop further is ok from time to time, but if you let it drop too low too often, it can shorten the overall battery lifespan. See this guide: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...ml#post4271880

I've had no problem with my GPS. Can you show you GPS settings page under location? Mine is set to high accuracy. Have you disabled location settings via App Off/Privacy Guard to stop battery drain?
Mine was set to high accuracy itself,still i tried changing it to device only also but still that didn't help.

i was having the same problem...i think i have a solution.
Before you go into your google maps, make sure your location is set to HIGH ACCURACY.

title: Rooting problem

thread.text:

replies.text: You're confusing two things here. Putting in 11S is updating. Adding su (a file) to /system/bin (a folder) is rooting.Are you sure this is a real OPO and it's manufactured for an English-speaking market? (One made for the Chinese market may be different - like an unlockable bootloader.)

title: Review: My OnePlus 1 is a Lemon (Rev

thread.text:
OK first off I am not new to Android or Android based smart phone's, started with the Google G1 on T-Mobile back then, I have owned about 12 different Android phones in the past 3 years, from just about every manufacturer, and have successfully rooted and ran custom ROM 's on about 4 of them. Just wanted to state that so you guys understand not a newbie and not "operator error" I received my 1+1 on Wednesday morning used it as much as possible through Friday night, ran it through every possible use as a daily driver. I sent a support ticket to OnePlus last night asking for an RMA to return it. Here's what I found on my particular phone :
First off is the infamous yellow tint on the bottom of the screen, really not a big deal and as an owner of a Oppo Find 7a, it was expected. Second thing, no matter what sound, profile or phone settings I use, the phone will never ring more than one time, miss hearing the first ring and you miss the call as it will never ring a second time. The charger and USB cable that comes with the phone is the only cable and charger that will change the phone without putting it in to an endless loop of rebooting. (note: this is a flaw, as others have stated that the can use any other USB cable or charger) while on the USB cable topic, it is a pretty cool red flat cable with unique looking ends on it, though it is pretty short. Next thing is touch screen response, not good, tried the different settings for touch sensitivity, no difference, put 4 phones together all on the same WiFi network all on the same websites. The 1+1 failed to sense the area touched on the screen about 30% of the time as opposed to the Oppo Find 7a, LG G2, and an HTC One M8. Over all it probably is a good phone for the price, I am giving OnePlus the benefit of the doubt and just assume I received a defective phone, I am not going to ask for a refund, I am asking them for a new phone. I will see how that goes, their response time on support tickets is a little slow, but I can understand that being a new stat up with a limited number of employees.
Posted via Android Central App

Yep. You got a lemon all right. A bummer to be sure but it happens. I have literally none of the issues you mentioned save a VERY slight yellow tinting at the bottom of the screen that I have to concentrate on to notice. Hope your RMA exchange (or refund) isn't a nightmare.
1+1/N5
Sorry to hear you have a lemon it sucks but with every phone their will be those that have issues. Let's hope they can quickly fix their manufacturing issues.
OP, what happened? Did they replace or refund?

replies.text: I got tired of the 2 week response time to support questions, I just kept the phone, did about 5 factory resets, did the 2 recent CM software updates, did another 2 factory resets, as of right now, I still have the yellow tint at the bottom of the screen, cell signal strength is not that good, but other than that it seems ok. Would I buy another one? That would be a big No.

title: Can I dual-boot my phone without an SD Card (Oneplus)?

thread.text:
Greetings! I was wondering if it is possible to Dual-boot with my 
phone without and SD Card (My Oneplus doens't support SD Cards).
I really want to try CM11S Nightly and Android 5.0 Lollipop without 
wiping my existant CM11S.
I have the Oneplus one 64GB (54GB Free). If there's a way to 
"split" the free space into smaller partitions and then install a 
new ROM onto it.
Or maybe there's an easier way to do it!
Thank you, Bout!

Hashcode did it with Safestrap, so there's definitely a way to do it. But I don't think there's an app out there to do it, you'd have to write one. (Safestrap is written, AFAIK, only for Samsungs with locked bootoaders. (You might also talk to the people at TWRP - Safestrap is basically TWRP with up to 4 extra slots. Maybe they could add slots as a standard in future versions.)
You don't split the free space, it just lets you choose which ROM image is going to boot when you boot the next time (pretty much like dual booting a PC).

title: Alarm Clock Occasionally Puts Phone In Airplane Mode

thread.text:
A few times in the morning I've awoken and discovered my phone in airplane mode. I thought some bug was possibly flipping it offline, but I started to suspect it may be connected to the alarm somehow.
This was confirmed last week as I had a mid-afternoon alarm go off while I was driving and listening to a podcast over Bluetooth. The alarm sound broadcast to the sound system, stopping the playback (or so I thought), but after dismissing the alarm podcast didn't resume. I tap the widget and the sound came from the phone. Then I noticed the dash display indicating there was no phone connected and that was because it had flipped to airplane mode at that moment.
This morning was the final straw: I'm a heavy sleeper, not a morning person and my job requires me to punch in within a very narrow 5-minute window, so I set an alarm clock, my phone's alarm AND my girlfriend calls to make sure I'm awake and not late for work. To help ease out of sleep, I have the alarms staggered - e.g. the phone is set for 7:06 with a 7-minute snooze, the alarm clock for 7:10 and my g/f calls at 7:15. Some combination will wake me up eventually. 
This morning the phone goes off, I snooze it; the alarm goes off, I snooze that. Around 7:20 the combination of the alarm and phone going off together wakes me up. I realize my g/f hadn't called and figured she may've forgotten to set her alarm until I see the airplane mode indicator. I get back online and start getting dressed for work and I could hear the voicemail chime; she'd been calling. She called about 7:42, sounding worried as hell and saying she'd tried to call me 8 times.
Anyone else seeing this behavior here and/or have a fix? TIA.

title: Is it still worth it?

thread.text:
Is it still worth buying the OPO when we're so close to a bunch of new phones? I have an HTC m8, lust after the OPO, but wonder if I should just wait it out for the next gen of phones. 
So, what do you say? Still worth getting?
Posted via Android Central App
If you sell the m8 for at least 350,then yeah, do it! If not, then you may wanna wait.

The OPO is still a great phone but it has some bugs (for example, auto rotate stopped working for me) perhaps, and it may not be as spectacular a value as it was a few months ago, but it is still a great value. Speaker isn't that great though.
Edit: a reboot has fixed my auto rotate. Actually, the OPO is still an extreme value due to cyanogenmod. It's not clear whether the next one will have it.

For phones that are factory unlocked and easy to root the OnePlus is awesome. It's still great hardware but there will be a bunch of new phones coming out this year with the next generation of processors and displays. The problem is that's an expensive game if you play it (but NEXT year...). I bought my OnePlus just for building custom things. Currently I've got the AOKP ROM on it (just for fun). It won't be the latest hardware next year (or even shortly) but it will still be good enough hardware for the next two years or so, which is all you can really expect from the consumer landfill industry that cellphones has become.

1) If you need a phone out of contract(IE: Paying full price) its still a great buy.
2) If your practical and don't care whether you have the latest phone its still a great buy.
3) If you don't mind waiting and perusing and participating in the One+ forums and can buy the instant you get an invite. Its still a great buy.

There's definitely a TON of factors that determine "Is it worth it?" but there's no doubt that for $300 out of contract there is no better Android device out there. So if you're looking for the best Android device at that price point, it's definitely worth it. In the past 6 months there has been many other devices that are equally as good if not better (Nexus 6, Note 4, Moto X, etc) but those are all $500 or more. If money is no object you may want to consider those devices but for money you're not going to get much better. I use a OnePlus One and an iPhone 6 everyday. There's not a huge difference in basic everyday tasks (web browsing, email, texting, facebook, instagram) and my iPhone cost me $749 ($400 more than the OnePlus One!). Obviously, using an Apple device has its benefits besides the basics but it's crazy to think you can get a very similar experience on a phone at the One's price point.

title: Driving Me Nuts!

thread.text: I am on AT&T. I was using an HTC one M7, and I had a problem with the WiFi. The phone would always try to connect to an open WiFi. This would not be a problem, except when a password or sign in was required, no connection was actually made. When this happened, I had no LTE or Wifi connection, and my push notifications would all stop because there was no internet connection. When I manually turned off WiFi, LTE would now start to work. However, a few minutes later, the WiFi would try to connect again, and I ounce again lost the internet connection. I never found a way to stop the WiFi from trying to connect to bad WiFi networks. I thought it was because of some At&T bloatware that I could not uninstall. So when I got the opo, I thought this would not be a problem anymore - WRONG! It does exactly the same thing. Is this the sim card that is doing that? How do I prevent the WiFi from connecting on it's own. Of course I turned it off in the settings - that does not work. This is driving me nuts!
Turn off constantly scanning in the WiFi settings. Also there's a setting to avoid weak connections. I'll post a screenshot if I can find it.

replies.text: Thank you so much. I'll try that! So far so good...

thread.text: In the WiFi settings tap the menu button and tap advanced and you'll see these options.

After some testing, it seems that I can now keep the WiFi from coming on if I have the "Scanning Always Available" box unchecked. However, that really does not solve the root problem. I seems that Android is not smart enough to use the good signal (WiFi or LTE) to maintain an internet connection. If WiFi is connected, but not functional (log in needed), LTE will not work. Very annoying...
Did you check Avoid Poor Connections?

replies.text: Yes, that box is checked. I walked all around my neighborhood and watched the phone. That will only avoid weak WiFi signals, not the ones that are not logged on. The ? always appears in the notifications and asks me to log on. BTW, I was surprised that almost every house had an Xfinity WiFi signal coming from it. As you know, Comcast uses home routers to broadcast public WiFi signals you can log on to. It just blows me away that nobody ever complains about this problem on forums. Am I the only one?

thread.text: Do you mean public WiFi connections? I always see private ones when I look for my router on the list. That is very weird if so.

replies.text: All Comcast routers have two WiFi signals - one is your private one, and one is for public use. If you have a Comcast account, you can use all the public (Xfinity) WiFi connections in peoples homes for free (millions of them potentially). All you have to do is log in with your Comcast password. That is why as I walk down my street, I am connecting to all the individual routers in peoples homes for free.

thread.text: Wow, I never knew that. I don't have Comcast but I wonder if something like that is going on with my cable WiFi.

title: Upgrade tips (Moto X -> OnePlus One) - I need some help

thread.text:
I'm going to be getting my OPO soon, I'll be upgrading from a Moto X on AT&T here in the USA. Is there a recommended guide to facilitate my transition? I've heard that there is a trick to keeping LTE coverage on the OPO as it's not officially supported by AT&T so it will possibly be relegated to HSDPA speed if I screw up.
I guess what I'm most confused about is how I activate the phone in the first place. I can't just transfer the sim cards as the Moto X uses a nanosim and the OPO uses a microsim card. If I go get a new microsim card from AT&T, what do I need to do/not do so I can keep my LTE? Or should I get an adapter tray for the sim card? I've read horror stories about those also... I'd rather use the correct sim card, so if it's possible I'd like to get a new microsim.
TIA
*disclaimer* - I'm a n00b to all this stuff, I had an iPhone until January of this year.

replies.text:
I did the same upgrade and like both . The opo is indeed a big phone. 
One neat thing is the one plus one has an adapter for both sized sim cards. 
Also the sim replacement isnt straightforward and can be put in backwards

thread.text:
"Tell them that you need a micro SIM card activated, but you don't have the device you'll be using with you present. Say that it's a Galaxy S5. The guys at the AT&T store will (probably) proceed to activate the SIM with a GS5, tricking AT&T into thinking that you're using that phone."
Does this look likely?

Coming from a Moto X, my tip is to get some bigger hands. 
That Sim card suggestion sounds reasonable and should work. If the rep you get doesn't go for it, just move on to another store.
Posted via Android Central App

You can always use a Nano to Micro adapter. Amazon has several available however I recommend spending the extra money and buy one where the Sim sits secure in the tray and not one held together by adhesive or tape. Your Lte should transfer over just fine.
Posted via Android Central App

replies.text:
I'm looking at one called MediaDevil, seen here. Amazon.com: MediaDevil Simdevil 3-in-1 SIM card adapter kit (Nano / Micro / Standard): Cell Phones & Accessories
A guy at Anandtech is recommending this one. Thoughts?

Just be cautious with these adapters. It's possible that they can get stuck in the device and if you try to force it out you can damage the SIM connections and cause real problems...like having to RMA your New device to China or wherever. Full disclosure: I was using a SIM adapter in my N5 (a carryover from the Moto x I used briefly), but I didn't want to risk getting it jammed in the oneplus. So I just picked up a new micro SIM from my local cricket store for $15. If you don't really need the adapter to hotswap between phones, I'd consider just picking up a micro SIM so you can use the tray the phone came with. Just My 0.02.
1+1/N5

thread.text:
The brands I recommend are Sadapter, or Noosy. I've had good luck with both brands.
Posted via Android Central App

If you are getting a new OPO, it will come with both a micro and nano SIM card tray. Just pop your SIM card in the OPO and you should be good to go. LTE will work just fine.
My OPO did not come with a nano tray but I used the sadapter from Amazon and it works great. I bought the OEM nano Sim tray for the OPO off of eBay for $10 and it works great. Now all three of my phones use a nano Sim card and I do not have to use an adapter. 
Posted via my Nexus 6!

I wound up buying a kit called SimDevil, came with 3 different sim adapters and works perfectly.
In the months since I got my OPO I've found that I like it a lot, with one exception: the radios (WIFI and LTE) are not as powerful as those in my OG Moto X. And I also like the Moto software features, hopefully the Lollipop update will bridge the gap between the OPO and the Moto X a bit.

I use the SimDevil adapters and find them to work well.
Never put an empty adapter into your phone! It will hang up on the pins.
Always take your time inserting and removing your sim. Never force it in or out.

title: I've got an internal debate going on here...

thread.text:
So I saw that the OnePlus one is on sale without an invite this Christmas, and I thought, what a fantastic opportunity. However.... I was considering getting an android wear watch since my AT&T contract is up in spring. I've got the GS4 on 4.4.4 but I'm ready to ditch carrier bloatware and waiting an eternity for updates. Although they're two totally different things, my question is; should I spend my money on a wear watch and continue to deal with AT&T's slow updates or get the OPO and wait on the Wear OS to become a bit more stable? I thought the phone is better because it's probably a once in a life time chance... But is it worth it?
Any thoughts and comments greatly appreciated, thanks.

replies.text:
This is the thought process that I live by when it comes to these things:
What do you use more often? The product that you use more often should be the thing that you get. You use your phone for everything (communicating, taking photos, gaming, browsing, etc.). The Wear watch, on the other hand, is more of a novelty. Be satisfied with your phone first, and if you have money to spare, consider investing in a Wear watch. 
Of course, neither is a necessity. One is, however, more necessary (or at least ubiquitous) than the other. You are not happy with your current phone, and the phone is something you need, use, and rely upon more often. Thus, you should get a new phone that'll make you happy.
Just my 2 Cents.

The OnePlus One is an awesome phone. I am on AT&T and getting rid of their bloat is nice. Their AT&T hotspot you are forced to turn off WIFI in order to get off of probably pissed me off the most. I was in a hotel once next to a Starbucks and since I could not get off the SLOW hotspot at Starbucks I was forced to use my data instead of Hotel WIFI. Anyway my vote is to lose the bloat first. Next gen Wear will be better anyway. I'm waiting doe NFC to be in the Wear watches before I get one.

thread.text:
That depends on how whatever carrier you're going to gives you the same coverage you need as AT&T does. If you're planning on staying with AT&T, stay on 4.4.4 until someone comes up with a rooting method for it, root and remove the bloatware.
The One Plus has a non-removable battery - for me that takes it completely off the consideration list. I won't use a device with a non-removable lithium battery (for a number of reasons). I don't care how good and/or how cheap the phone is. I love the M8, but won't even consider it for a free phone and unlimited everything for free.

Yeah I'm staying on AT&T. I want the OPO mainly because of CM. rooting the AT&T GS4 isn't possible because of the locked bootloader I think (from what I remember reading) what's important for me is no carrier bloat and direct, fast updates from CM. I think between AW and the OPO I'd rather spend my money on the phone because it's a one time opportunity. Android wear can wait and they can make better versions, who knows if I'll ever get a chance to buy the OPO again. It's a debate I have going in my head. Plus, I already had rooted it on 4.4.2 and I couldn't get the OTA's from AT&T because I had deleted the bloatware and the bloat is necessary for it to update... Plus I'm sick of touchwiz, I've only ever had galaxy phones and I'm ready for a change of pace. I was looking at the N6 but again, it will still get held back by AT&T unless I drop 600+ to get it unlocked. Also, I just watched the Android Authority review of it and it DOES have a removable back cover, albeit a bit difficult to remove.

I've also heard something about a bug with the screens on the OPOs... Something about yellow lines? Has that been fixed? I've also heard about the call volume being very quiet. Have both of those been fixed by now?

title: OnePlus One: Now comes the decision. Keep or sell?

thread.text:
Okay I've been using the OPO for a week now as my daily driver, and its really nice. It really is. I'm lucky in that mine doesn't have a yellow screen or volume issues. Now I'm faced with a decision.
Do I keep it or do I sell it?
Here's my situation...I have an iPhone 5S, an iPad Air, and the OPO. I truly am amazed at what OPO has done with this phone. But I'm a girl, with girl hands, girl pockets, and the OPO is BIG. Like bigger than my M8 was which I could deal with, but just barely. My sweetspot has always been a 4.5-7 inch screen. And I just don't know if I can live day to day with the size of the phone. 
So here are the options I'm mulling over:
1) Suck it up and try to learn to deal with it, and the fact that I have to leave it on my desk in the back room because it simply doesn't fit in my dress pant pockets. Women's dress pants are stupid. 
2) Sell it. I already know I'm buying the iPhone 6, so I would put the proceeds towards that purchase. I always end up back on iPhone, it seems, but having the iPad makes it even more convenient with the way they talk to each other. I wouldn't make a profit, I'd sell it at cost and eat the duty I paid for bringing it into Canada. I'll end up down about $80 in the end, I figure. I can live with that. Its a week old, its not been abused lol. 
3) Go back to iPhone. Keep the OPO because its unlocked in case I ever go on vacation and need a phone I can use anywhere. 
In the last year I've owned the Galaxy S3, iPhone 5, HTC One M7 and M8, iPhone 5S, BB Z10, BB Q5...it seems I love playing with phones but always end up back with Apple. I suppose it makes sense with the iPad...
Decisions decisions.

title: Which one is better the Sony Xperia Z3 or Oneplus One?

thread.text: Which is better overall phone?

replies.text:
That's a matter of opinion. Therefore that's up to you to decide
Posted via...The One

thread.text:
The one that will not have a replacement in February or every 6 months depending on when you get it
Posted via my OnePlus One!

I actually bought both of these phones because they were the 2 I was most interested in upgrading to from my Nexus 5. I can give you my opinions of the two.
The OPO is a great value. 350 bucks for a 64gb phone off contract is awesome. The phone feels really well built and the size is fine for me. I think the "grippiness" of the back makes dealing with a larger phone much better. The battery life on this phone compared to my Nexus has been great. I don't see a time when I wouldn't easily be able to get through an entire day (from waking up until going to bed) with this phone. The software is fast and insanely customizable. One thing that i noticed out of the box was that Cyanogen puts a number on the notification tray icons to indicate how many notifications you have from an app. This really annoyed me because it made it hard to see the app icon so I went searching through the settings and sure enough, I could just disable that.  I'm not sure what I think of the camera so far. It seems to get focus faster than my Nexus (which doesn't take much) but I feel like even in outdoor shots I notice noise when I zoom in on them. I would have expected less noise given the higher MP count, though I'm no photographer by any means.
I bought the Z3 unlocked from Sony for 630 dollars so right away we're talking about nearly double the price of the OPO. I know the OPO is a rarity with its price, but it is something to consider. The Z3 is also very well built, though the glass back is quite slippery. I would definitely get a case for this phone. Like the OPO, the battery life is great. Once again, I don't think there's any way that I would burn through this battery before a full day was up. The software on the Z3 is pretty nice. It isn't too far from stock, which I like. Where this phone fails, in my opinion, is the camera. I had high hopes for this camera because of all of the reviews saying how great it was. And while it may be great for taking nice still landscape shots, it is HORRIBLE for trying to get pics of kids that are running around. The time between hitting the shutter button and the actual picture being taken is ridiculously long. I tried the Timeshift Burst mode, which is cool and works pretty well, but the pics are only taken at 1920x1080 resolution. If that mode was at least the 8MP resolution that the Superior Auto mode produces I would be fine with that, but 1920x1080? No thanks.
I place high importance on the camera on my phone since it is the only device that I will carry with me everywhere I go. With 2 young kids I like being able to get quality pictures from my camera. I know a lot of people say you should get a real camera if you want good pictures but I disagree. Having used several iPhones in the past, I was perfectly pleased with the shots I got from them. The OnePlus One doesn't match the iPhone 6 camera quality, but given the price difference (350 vs 750 for 64gb) and my preference for Android over iOS, I'm inclined to choose the OPO.

title: Use of Profiles

thread.text:
I am wondering how everyone uses the Profiles? Seems like too many clicks to get there...Widgets? Also, is there a way to automate when the Profiles are turned on? 
Thanks.
Posted via the Android Central App

I use Tasker to automate it. 
Night Profile defined by time of day. 
Automotive profile that starts when my phone connects with my car bluetooth. 
Headphone profile when my headphones connect. 
Then a default profile for the times in between 
I also have one called silent that I use the notification shade widget to turn on and off. I use it for movies. If I don't even have to say on it since when I get in my car the automotive profile starts. 
I really like the profiles.

Profiles can start based on wifi or bluetooth and it is built into the profile. It is on the bottom in profiles. Then you can start a profile with an alarm using the stock alarm clock.

title: Problem trying to order OnePlus One

thread.text: I'm trying to order this phone, but the website is extremely slow today. When I click Checkout, after a while I am brought to an "Edit Account Information" page that asks for my first and last name. I enter them and click Save, but nothing happens....ever. I've tried this on both Chrome and Safari with no luck. Has anyone seen this before? I'm worried that my invite will expire before I'm actually able to buy the phone. Ugh.
The web site is incredibly buggy. If you can't get your order through, make a note of your invite code and send it with an email explaining the problem to the OnePlus zendesk support email.

Yeah says I'm not a member even after I pre ordered this past Monday. I can't log in even though I got an email saying my pre order was successful. Paypal says pending though. I was hoping to not run into any problems with them but I think I'll just pass on parting with my money this time around.
Posted via the Android Central App

Well, I was able to place my order. The issue that I was having was an error with their website. I was about to give up last night when I saw a thread on their forums where a lot of people were having the same problem as me. One person got around it by looking at the source code of the Save button, saving some of it to a local html file and opening that file. Doing that would show the first and last name boxes with the Save button. I tried the same thing and to my surprise, it worked. All of this has me nervous that if I have any problem with the phone it will be a nightmare getting support, but given the price for what you get, I'm taking the chance.
Yeah there were some glitches with the site the other night, I was trying to order too. It still was a ton easier than chasing that damn 6 around for 3 weeks and still not being able to order it. Lol

title: No wireless charging on the OnePlus One?

thread.text:
So I guess its safe to assume the One+ won't have QI wireless charging going by OnePlus specs on their site..real bummer everything else on this phone seems to fire on all cylinders. 
Sent from my SAMSUNG-SM-G900A using Tapatalk
Wireless charging is fastfood for a battery a real horrible way to charge. I am happy it is not included.

replies.text: Is it bad to charge a battery using a wireless qi charger? What will happen to the battery?

Induction charging also known as wireless charging is not good in the long term because wireless charging does not allow for cell balancing. To generate a (for a lack of a better way to put it) "clean" induction field is not a cheap thing to do. Most people are not willing to spend $200-$400 for a high quality induction charger.
Since most people have no way of testing the induction field the manufactures are selling low quality units and damaging the longevity of customer batteries. I have to admit that most people don't even use their devices long enough to notice the lose because we are only talking about a 10%-15% lose. I bet most people would also find that acceptable for the convenient charging solution. Just like how many also eat fast food which also kills us slowly.

I'm no electrical engineer, but I've been using a qi wireless charger on my GS3 for nearly 18 months and have noticed no negative effects from it. Not saying it isn't possible, but the time frame we will use a piece of cellular technology may not be long enough for us to see the impact.
That being said, if the 1+1 had qi charging, I would certainly use it. What people seem to be missing is that some of the higher end features have been omitted to keep the device at a certain price point. Without the removable battery, I don't foresee a third party replacement cover enabling qi.

Agree... I was using wireless charging with my GS3 for over a year with no noticeable negative effect.... and I've been using nothing but wireless charging since I got my Nexus 5 and Nexus 7, 2013.... I have not physically plugged a phone or tablet up in almost a year now..... I got a wireless charger on my desk and at home on the kitchen counter... 
If the do not offer a wireless charging back for the One+ One it will only be a minor thing... I am sure there will be (as someone else stated) a secondary market for one eventually... I Like it.. a lot easier than fumbling around with a cord but at the same time fumbling around with a cord isn't THAT big a deal....

Why would this be? My understanding is that cell balancing is a core battery technology, not dependent on charging method. And the WPC Qi charging standard in fact is capable of knowing when to turn off/slow down. (Source: Texas Instrument). If the battery itself is capable of communicating information on charging, there is no reason that information cannot be relayed through Qi charging coils, and it seems to me that it is.
Well you keep guessing.

I'm not trying to be argumentative. I'm trying to understand the scientific and technological evidence behind the argument that inductive charging renders power balancing inactive. From my research, it doesn't seem to be true. I am merely asking for other contrary evidence, if available.
Sent from my Nexus 5 using Tapatalk

Come off it. This is complete nonsense. 
A phone battery only has one cell, there is no balancing to be done, further more the power still goes through the phones charging circuit which will make sure it is within specs for the battery.
If you want a simple non BS reason why wireless charging is bad, it is because wireless chargers generate waste heat (induction charging is lossy and the lost energy goes into heat), heat is bad for lithium-ion batteries that all phones use these days, and it will reduce the useful life of the battery.
But in spite of this issue with wireless charging I still use it for the convenience, although if my phone is too hot (e.g. after a long gaming session), I'll plug it in rather than use the wireless charger.
Posted via Android Central App

Actually there is no charge circuit within Lithium-ion battery powered devices. There is a fire protection circuit within the battery that slowly increases resistance as the battery reaches full which is detected and reacted to. So do some research before trying to sound smart. You are right there is only one cell but you missed that it was just a trap-door point for people with no point but to disprove the message would latch on to. Notice none of the rest of my post even brings it back up.

I didn't say the charge circuit was in the battery, I said it was in the phone, and there most certainly is one in pretty much every phone. It may be part of the main SoC or it may be a separate chip, but it will be there. It seems you are trying to twist my words in order to sound smart.Oh, so you intentionally put in incorrect information in order to elicit a response? That's the hallmark of a troll.
Posted via Android Central App

Perhaps the best solution would be to offer a removable battery and wireless charging capabilities? If the battery gets worn out, the customer can change it with a fresh battery. I believe wireless charging is very popular, but if it damages the battery, it will be a negative feature over the long term.
The phone does not come with a removal battery or wireless charging to keep the price down.

Got any proof other than your opinion since I been using Qi charging on my Nexus 5 with no issues. Also, I hear that the majority of phones sold in Japan have had wireless charging for years. I would buy my wife a OPO but I would never own another phone that doesn't have that feature. I can always replace my battery since they all go bad if you hang on to them long enough. There are videos and batteries on how to replace my N5's battery that would take a few minutes.

By personal opinion.
Sent from my SAMSUNG-SM-G900A using Tapatalk

thread.text: With a switchable battery back it wouldn't surprise me if someone comes out with something. Hope to see it but its not a deal breaker by any means. In fact I'm not even really sure this will replace my M7 yet.

So I guess you DO have to compromise! Lol @One Plus marketing scam 
Sent from my XT1060 using AC Forums mobile app

Lack of wireless charging might keep me from buying this device. Maybe they will add it with a new back cover like the S5.
Once you go with wireless charging it is hard to go back.
Posted via Android Central App

I adopted QI since the nexus 4 and own two Nexus 2013 chargers now, I'll never go back to wired charging !
Its defiantly a deal breaker for me, as for cell balancing is it not controlled by the charging circuit ? 
I always balance charge LIPOs for my quad but theory are short bursts of high usage, smart phones slowly discharge so cell balance is less of an issue.
Posted via Android Central App

Does anybody else realize that a USB also has no charging circuit. Phones contain their own charging circuits because they almost all have different batteries. Wireless charging isnt what you would call clean but that refers to the loss of energy (lack of efficiency) by using induction so the fallacy that somehow wireless charging is bad for your battery is completely unfounded. When's the last time you bought a cheap charger from Walmart? cuz I guarantee there is no charging circuit in there and very little to prevent any sort of damage to your phone.
Posted via Android Central App
its not offical
Too bad

WHAT? "Does not allow for cell balancing"? And how exactly would you "cell balance" a single 4.2v cell, killer? Answer: You don't.
Induction charging works JUST FINE when implemented properly. If you buy a cheap Qi charger, expect crappy results. I have been using a Tylt Qi charger with my Lumia 1520 for a year now, every night, and it works just fine. 
Wow. I guess if you can't dazzle someone with your brilliance, you can baffle them with your BS instead. "Cell Balancing" a single-cell phone battery. Now THAT's funny.

title: Doubletwist compatibility with OnePlus One?

thread.text:
I have recently purchased a OnePlus One to replace my iPhone 4. I have an extensive collection of music on iTunes, and listen to it regularly during my morning commute. I am not willing to use my data to stream the music, so Google Music is out of the question. 
After looking around online for the best Android-friendly iTunes replacement, I settled on downloading Doubletwist. I immediately encountered a problem, however, when I realized my phone cannot be mounted on my Mac as a disc drive. Doubletwist's solution to this problem is the Air Sync feature, which, of course, costs money. I have no problem paying, but I want to be sure it actually works. 
On a side note, I've tried the standard drag and drop with AFT, but for some reason it skips over a bunch of songs. While I am aware that Google Music is primarily a streaming service, is it possible to permanently store music on a device through the system without losing various tags and album artwork?

replies.text:
Use Google music to send your iTunes music to the cloud, it's the easiest, and free. You can then pin the play lists or albums you want to your device to not have to stream all the time when away from Wi-Fi. 
Otherwise you could look into Plex, it turns your computer into a media streaming server both for your iTunes library and any other media you might have, like movies. Www.Plex.tv

Airsync worked with my OPO without issues.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text: You do know that you can download music to your OPO with Google Play Music, right?https://support.google.com/googlepla.../1250232?hl=en

title: A Better Camera App?

thread.text:
In HDR mode, Google's Camera app captured beautiful pictures on my Nexus 5 but I'm finding it doesn't produce the same quality on the OPO. I tried reinstalling it a couple of times because I was amazed that the images it captured, whether Auto or HDR, weren't as good as the CM 11S Camera app that is pre-installed on the OPO. The biggest flaw was the focus. In Auto, Clear Image and HDR mode, the CM 11S consistently captured better quality images than Google's Camera app, Camera FV-5 and ProCapture 2.
I'm finding that the Auto setting is great for quick shots and for more stationary subject matter Clear Image can produce some stupendous shots with smaller file sizes [than Auto].
Any feedback on better third-party camera apps?
Here's an image comparison chart from GSMArena as a side note.
Secondary question; there seems to be no setting to silence the Camera app, either...? Thanks.

title: After day one

thread.text:
Picked up the phone Saturday and my son and I have not put I it down. This is going to replace my Moto X 2013. I didn't think I could give up Moto display but I can deal with tap to wake. Now all I have to do is score another one in the pre-order tomorrow. Hope it ships as fast lol. 
In case anyone is wondering the new tool apple gives you to get out of imessage is a joke. My son is not getting text from anyone with an iPhone. It actually says you do not need the tool if you sign out of imessage. Still did not work. 
Battery on this thing is crazy. My son had over 5 hours screen on time with most of that playing the games with the best graphics be could find. He also said he could tap the screen a lot faster to do something in a game. I don't know but it seemed to impress him. 
Cyanogen is incredible. I have never used it before. So much customization and the lock screen is awesome. 
So far we love this phone. Enough to try and buy another tomorrow for myself.
Posted via Android Central App

replies.text:
Sign out and turn off imessage on all devices that use his account before removing the SIM card from iPhone. 
I switch back and forth and have not had an issue.

title: Horrible advertising, horrible way to sell.... BUT

You cannot help but be impressed with this device. I received mine today after getting an invite only yesterday some how my phone came over night from CA to OH... That's impressive alone seeing as I paid for standard shipping. This phone is one of the nicest phones out going by looks. 
The screen is superb. Very detailed and good colors and nice and bright.
The black backing is great with that soft sandpaper feeling, it doesn't feel cheap at all.
The camera seems to take some really nice pics, much better than my M8
And the sound isn't all that bad neither.
Performance wise the 3gb of ram makes this fly. I'm very impressed with the speed of this device.
$364 shipped is such good value. I was going with a Nexus 6 but after the delay by a week I decided to take a chance and I don't regret it one bit
Probs nothing none of you have heard before.

title: Dropped calls on AT&T LTE

thread.text:
Is no one else w a OPO experiencing instant dropped calls? If you're on AT&T and have LTE enabled calls drop instantly after a ring or the other end of the call says "Hell...". oh.
Its a known big problem. https://jira.cyanogenmod.org/plugins...sue/BACON-1665
Basically the phone on AT&T LTE is currently useless as a phone.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: What do you mean AT&T LTE? Phone calls don't use data...
I'm experiencing the same thing. If you're connected to an LTE network on AT&T, phone will not make or receive a call.

thread.text: Since when is that happening? The LTE data was wonky on Cricket a week back but this is the first I'm hearing of trouble with calls with the OPO.

replies.text: Mine started having problems 2 days ago. It's currently unusable without turning off LTE or data completely.
Have you reported it to AT&T?

Multiple users are reporting it to AT&T. Their response has been more of, we'll look at it, but we don't really support unlocked phones.
Here is a 9 page thread on it. Just check out the official forum, it's littered with people having this exact problem.https://forums.oneplus.net/threads/c...update.152486/
Thanks, I'll check it out if I can. I've been planning on putting my OPO on an ATT MVNO, and I don't see evidence yet that they're similarly affected.

thread.text: I have had my Oneplus One for about a week and have made quite a few calls (on ATT). I haven't dropped a call yet. I know this doesn't help the folks that are having this issue, but at least it's not happening to everyone.
This appears to be an issue in the Northeast and may be related to ATT and VoLTE testing?
I had ZERO dropped calls on my 2 OPO phones for 60+ days. ZERO. I'm on ATT in northeast USA.

replies.text:
I was on the thread here and read through the thread on the oneplus forums and it seemed pretty widespread in the northeast. Also saw a thread regarding it on the Nexus 5 so the theory was that non att branded devices were having issues while att was testing VoLTE. 
Just bought another OPO, so the thread caught my attention but it seems it was a regional issue. Glad you have not been affected!
Posted via Nexus 5

thread.text:
The temporary solution is to switch you preferred Network to 3G when you need to receive or make calls. Switch back to LTE when you need high Data rates. 3G is more than enough for any streaming App. 
It affects unlocked phones. My Nexus 5 has the issue as well. I have complained to the FCC, suggest everyone do the same. On the new iphones, which have also reported this problem, they can check a box that has voice use 3G. Not an option for most of us.
This issue can be fixed by either At&t or Cyangenmod. The phone is trying to switch off LTE itself, but for some reason is hanging up in the transition. 
Its occurring for me only in PA. When I traveled to VA, MD and WV this week it worked normally. Thats with my N5 the One+ should be the same.

replies.text:
Yep. Nexus 5 stock not rooted- same problem. I see it posted all over. Before I read that I was bit alone, I thought it was the phone and talked Google into swapping out a new handset to me. Guess what? Same problem. Called AT&T, explained it all to them, they said, "Huh?" And never got back to me.
Anybody know of a way to keep data pegged to LTE, but tell the phone to make all calls on 3G- before the call is started?

The iphone 6 has a setting for this, but not us. I am still looking for a widget to do this...Right now I am just using LTE and if I get a call or have to make a call I manually switch to 3G. It is a pain, still only takes a second or two.

thread.text: I just got the one. LTE worked perfectly yesterday. Now I am getting dropped calls on LTE. I switched to 3g and no dropped calls. Very annoying! I may have to bring this to ATT store and have them help me sort this out.

replies.text: It's because of AT&T testing VoLTE. Complain to the FCC.

thread.text:
We may be closer to having At&t fix their Voice Over LTE(VoLTE) testing. Fri Nov 7th no dropped calls in the Phila area while using my N5.(Also all of DE.) I'll be testing the One+ on LTE today around Phila to see if the problem has abated for both phones. Between At&t and the Update to CM11 we should be closer to a fix.
Keep checking each day and see if your area clears up...

was* having this problem for the past two weeks. Live in NYC and have the OPO 64 on AT&T. When connected to 4G (no wifi) every made or received call would automatically hangup after 5-10 seconds 100% percent of the time. Only when I switched to 3G or connected to wifi did the phone not hangup. Like many have speculated the culprit was AT&T VoLTE
as of today I received the 44S updated which not only fixes annoying random reboots and instability, issues with the black bar/artifacts, BUT also the AT&T VoLTE issue. I have made one phone call after the update and everything seems good now with 4G on but lets see how the update pans out after 1-2 weeks.
the update is regional for now so if you can't get it OTA, you can always download it online

It's fixed for me, too. LTE data on, calls connect and phone drops back to "H" (HSPA+) without dropping me. Nexus 5, AT&T, NYC
It may be that AT&T fixed something- many folks no longer have the issue. It may be coincidental that you got an update to your OPO as well.

title: Can I put my iPhone sim card into my new OnePlus?

thread.text:
I want to move my Verizon SIM card out of my iphone 4S
to my soon to arrive OnePlus. Can I swap between these phones
with this same card?
Am I going to need to change the APN settings on the OPO
to get this to work?
Also, will I need an adaptor to hold the SIM card?
Thx!

According to reviews and other user experiences on the web, the OnePlus One is not compatible with Verizon's CDMA network. So although the microSIM card from your iPhone would fit, you wouldn't be able to make any phone calls. You'd presumably be able to access LTE for data, and could consider VOIP calls. Not sure if the One will be able to make VoLTE calls, once Verizon turns that on nationwide.

The sim in a Verizon device is to use on GSM networks. Although the Verizon devices come gsm unlocked, The OPO will not work in Verizon in the US because the network is CDMA and the OPO has GSM radios.
Go get a droid turbo! 
Posted via my OnePlus One!
The OPO actually has a WCDMA radio, but that still isn't compatible with the Verizon network.

title: Thinking about buying a OnePlus One? I wouldn't.

thread.text:
I've had my OnePlus One over a month now, and it's been far from a smooth experience. Everyone praises the specs on the phone at the price point its offered. I'd agree, spec wise, at this price point, it seems like a fantastic phone. However, in execution, it fails to deliver big time.
I'm not going to get into the positives on the phone, everyone's read them and truthfully I'm ready to throw this thing in the trash. Full disclaimer, I've never rooted or installed any ROM/update to my OPO that wasn't pushed directly to the phone. I've factory reset the phone 3 times in 2 weeks and have seen the same problems repeat themselves.
Starting with the hardware, the screen more specifically. It's Gorilla Glass, yet somehow, I've managed to scratch the screen. I never use screen protectors on phones, I don't like the tactile feedback from them. I've been using smart phones since resistive touch screens with styluses and since Windows Mobile, and I've NEVER scratched a screen, ever. Somehow, my OPO screen got scratched and it's never been dropped. Maybe it's a coincidence, but it's worth noting given as I've never scratched or cracked a screen.
The GPS is slow to track many times. Using Google Navigation, I'll make the suggested route move, and the GPS thinks I missed the turn and will start recalculating. It corrects itself after it catches up, but it does this quite frequently.
Let's talk about the software, oh the software. The software on this phone is horrendous. It's absolutely positively filled with bugs. It feels like you're using a nightly ROM from your favorite creator. I consistently experience random reboots during phone calls, general usage or just sitting on my desk at work. Apps crash out constantly. I've experienced quite a few problems with Google Maps crashing constantly requiring reboots to get it to work.
The absolute BIGGEST problem I've seen so far is something that many OPO users are experiencing. The phone will NOT make a phone call when connected to an LTE network and not WiFi. It lets you dial, it connects, you hear the person on the other end and within 1-5 seconds of the call, the phone hangs up. It's not a proximity sensor issue, as I can put the phone on the desk on speaker and be no where near it and it will still drop calls. You have to turn off LTE to get the phone to make a call. As someone who uses their phone as a phone for work, this is completely UNACCEPTABLE. The phone is unusable currently on LTE, so in my opinion, it's a worthless paper weight.
In closing, I'll be moving to a Galaxy Note 4 or Nexus 6 shortly. The phone is not working out. I guess it's true what the say, you get what you pay for. With the OPO, you're getting a basket case of a phone that no one wants to say anything negative about.

I use the phone on At&t and have never had a problem making a call on LTE, nor have I heard of this before. I actually think the call quality is excellent. My signal strength was a little better with the S5, which is to be expected from a Samsung device. It was the same story when the S5 was compared to the Nexus 5 also. thread.text: Was Google Play Music preinstalled, or did you have to install it yourself? If it was preinstalled, try booting into Safe Mode, which disables all 3rd party apps. If the problem goes away, then something you've installed is interfering. Tap OK.

Features-to-price, it definitely seems like a good deal. Their emphasis on security, too, is pretty appealing. It's also a stylish device. I would say, though, that I'd get my hands on one first. My wife isn't home(With the One+) and I am taking the pic with my N5(Which has the same microusb orientation). Here is an N4 in a case(Backwards) in the dock to give you an idea what it looks like it.
The little tray comes out to allow a phone with a case...With no case on than you would leave it in. On the back you have a Micro USB and a full USB. So I tested it with the Micro plugged in. A secondary device can charge with the Full USB. Also it comes with a very short USB to Micro USB cable....and here are some pics.
Its not as convenient as Qi charging, but for $10 shipped its certainly worth it. If you like your phone standing up. My wife has the clock on the lock screen when charging, so it acts as an easy to read nightstand clock.
Its slightly faster plugging into the dock than plugging in the cord itself, since you don't have to orient the plug to tell which way to put it in. You still need to be gentle as you plug it in, to make sure it is lined up...but all docks are that way.

title: OnePlus One or iPhone 6

thread.text:
I have an iPhone 6 but before that I had the LG G3, HTC One M8, Note 3, Nexus 5, OnePlus One (defective), Galaxy S5, Xperia Z1S, Moto X, LG G2, Find 7a, and the iPhone 5. 
I know it's kind of dumb to ask this question especially in a OnePlus One forum but I am having issues making up my mind. 
"OPO or iP6"
I have an iPhone 6 as mentioned before and a OnePlus One is on the way. Do I refuse the OnePlus One and keep the iPhone 6 or return the iPhone 6 and keep the OPO. 
I'm currently using JUMP to finance the iPhone 6. If I keep the OPO then I can JUMP to a Note 4, Moto X, or even an iPhone 6 should I feel the need. However that's a waste of money. 
I like iOS and Android but at the same time I hate them both. I like iOS's standardization but hate their locked down approach. I like the app selection on iOS but hate it's simplicity. I also like how iOS works better with my current things. Like my car stereo and home entertainment system. I like Android for its customization and openness. Meaning I don't have to use Google stuff if I don't want to unlike iOS. I have to use Apple stuff. Even iOS new third party keyboard addition. I'm still constantly reminded I have Apple keyboard installed. For some reason iOS "forgets" I wanted to use SwiftKey. I also wish iOS had a 7 minute app test period too. 
I wish Android updated faster on all phone. That's one of my biggest complaints. Not only that I wish app development was easier for developers... Oh what's that Android L does. Great, but unfortunately it'll be a slow change. Which is why I want to stick with Android. Android L will do a lot for Android. 
What to do what to do dammit. 
I wish I can get a visit from both my future selves and have them both tell me about their experience. One that stuck with Android and the other that kept iOS. 
It doesn't help that most of my friends aren't techy and have iDevice. So iMessage is kind of nice. Video, voice, and mms along with group chat is pretty damn nice. 
All my techie friends clearly say ditch the POS iPhone. We group chat on hangouts but its still limited. 
Then there's the fact I get a decent Android experience on iOS with all the Google Apps on iOS. I know it's no where near as good as Android but it's kind of nice lol. 
Anyway I know the ultimate decision is me and I'm the only one that knows what to do but I'd love to hear from you guys on this. 
Thanks 
Mike aka Vahdyx

replies.text: It also depends on how heavily invested you are in a particular OS.

thread.text: I'm in a similar, but opposite quandary. Right now I've got an M8 and was a long time iOS user. This is actually my first Android device. There are things I love about my M8 (screen, speakers, I prefer Android's homescreens, I really love Sense stock keyboard, cheaper expandable storage, etc.). But there are some ways I prefer iOS (overall experience, better camera, apps run smoother and look more modern, deep integration with my Mac and iTunes, my closest friends use iDevices so iMessage is amazing). I don't really use Google services at all. In fact, I kind of find Google Now to be pointless. So far for me all it's done is voice activated Google search. Once I get past the homescreens I prefer the design of iOS as well. Especially messaging, mail, and browsing. I know I can customize with Android, but if I like the way iOS handles stock, then I don't feel like I should have to customize. The thing is there are more things I like about the iPhone 6 than the M8, but I'm just not sure if I can go down in screen size/quality, the size of Sense keyboard, better home screen implementation, and speakers vs the overall smoother experience of iOS. I feel your pain. I kinda miss the days of having fewer excellent phone options so there's less to regret. Hahaha! j/k

Opo and keep your money r your jump on somethig else.
Opo will get updates rather quick!
Btw with the iphone you will always neef to bring your charger along, duo to its small battery!
Posted by my G3 or my 1+

The quick answer is that you can't go wrong either way but it depends more on your preferences. 
If you want a bigger screen, a "possibly" better camera, 4K recording, massive customization, and want to save a lot of money while doing so the OnePlusOne is a no brainer. 
If you believe a 4.7 inch screen would suit you better, you like recording slow-mo and have the money to get an iPhone it'll also be great. 
But both phones will be getting software updates for over two years and both are great, the main consideration are your preferences and the amount of money you are willing to spend on either.

Since you can get a good Google experience on the iPhone and you aren't sure if you want a OPO, I'd say stick with the iPhone. If you were sure, you'd get the OPO.

I was interested to see this thread here. I am struggling with the same decision. I have had my G3 since launch and received my OPO about 2 weeks ago. I have used the G3 as my daily driver for several months, and have been using the OPO for 2 weeks now as my daily phone. 
To me, the G3 has some advantages:
* I prefer its form factor and in hand feel of the G3 to the OPO. Its much smaller than the OPO with the same 5.5 inch screen size. Being more narrow and a bit more rounded feels much better to me. I also like the back better. I am not a fan of the sandstone back and wish there was a way to get a replacement. I never use a case on any of my phones. This is a big one for me- may not be for other people.
* The G3 screen is far superior to the OPO. I am not talking about specs, but the side to side look of the screens. The G3 is much more vibrant and a bit clearer. I don't have the yellowing problem on my OPO so I can't comment on that. This is not to say the OPO screen is not good, but side by side to the G3 it seems washed out.
* I like having the option of a replaceable battery on the G3. I travel sometimes and this is very handy.
* The camera seems to be better on the G3, but both cameras are faily good so this is not a huge factor for me.
The G3, however, has one major issue that I can't seem to get around. When I load it up with my daily use email, social and other apps, it gets unreliable. It often overheats and will randomly reboot. I have reset the device several times and even had a replacement sent from AT&T but it still is not reliable. I thought initially it might be the screen that was causing the issue, but the phone runs flawlessly for days on a charge with the SIM card out with only WIFI connected. Maybe its the radio, I don't know, but not being reliable is is a pretty big negative.
The OPO on the other hand has been rock solid for the 2 weeks I have been using it. I miss the in hand feel and smaller size of the G3 even after trying to adjust to the OPO. 
The OPO also has some additiona strengths over the G3 I should list:
* Fast, reliable software. The G3 launcher is noticeably laggy. This can be fixed somewhat with ApexLauncher or some other launcher, but I still think these run slower on the QHD screen.
* Value for the money. Cost is not a big issue for me, but if it is for you then the OPO is the clear choice.
* The battery life is very good and very consistent. I can always count on it to act predictably. The G3 was the opposite. It would start to heat up suddenly and in an hour it would tear through half the battery even while off in my pocket.
* Software updates do not have to go through the carrier. I am thinking this phone will get Android L long before the AT&T G3.
All in all, a tough choice. If the G3 worked predictably for me, I would probably choose it because of its better screen, form factor, and slightly better camera. But unless I can figure out this heat up, reboot, and battery drain issues, the OPO is looking like the choice for my daily driver. I will probably keep both for a while and tinker around with the G3 to see if I can figure out why it is so unreliable.
Sent from my Surface Pro 3 using Tapatalk
